awd_titl_txt: The Role of Cell Cycle Regulation in Leaf Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Ultimately, all of the world’s food supply, as well as many other crucial products, depend on energy harvested from sunlight by plants. This sunlight is captured by leaves that have shapes optimized for light harvesting while minimizing water loss. Leaves of some plants are also adapted to growing in extreme environments such as high stress or high salt conditions, showing that there are genetic controls of growth responses to the environment. Understanding how leaves adapt to the environment through cell growth will provide foundational information for a resilient and sustainable agriculture in the face of changing environments. Leaves generally grow by increasing cell number through division followed by an increase in cell size by expansion. It is not clear how these two processes of division and expansion are controlled to give rise to the final shape of a leaf. This research explores the function of a family of regulators that restrict cell division and promote the switch to cell expansion in the genetic model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The findings are then applied to study how cell expansion is controlled in response to  salt exposure in leaves of the salt-adapted plant Schrenkiella parvula.  Understanding how plants can grow in extreme salt-stressed conditions will provide basic information about how plants respond and adapt to the environment. The next generation of scientists will be trained in hands-on research through experience in the laboratory and by developing course-based undergraduate research projects in plant biology. 

	The SIAMESE-RELATED (SMR) family of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors, first discovered in the Larkin lab, are key regulators of the transition from cell proliferation to endoreplication, an alternate version of the cell cycle in which DNA replication continues without subsequent division.  Two family members, SMR1 and SMR2, have distinct effects on leaf cell number, cell size and overall leaf size in Arabidopsis thaliana. Our central hypothesis is that SMRs serve as key regulators of leaf growth for both developmental and environmental cues by controlling the timing and extent of endoreplication during leaf development.  This hypothesis will be tested by examining the regulation and functional roles of the SMR1 and SMR2 genes during leaf development, and by examining the role of SMRs in Schrenkiella parvula leaf development in response to salt treatment.  This work will contribute to the identification of regulatory networks controlling the onset of endoreplication in leaves, and to understanding the role of endoreplication in leaf function and stress adaptation, and will develop resources for the extremophyte model S. parvula. The proposed work will play a role in the education of three graduate students and several undergraduates from a wide diversity of backgrounds.  A course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) lab focusing on gene expression is also planned, using SMR promoter:reporter fusion transgenic lines that will be produced as part of the proposed research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit:

The goal of this project was to understand how growth of plant organs is regulated, particularly in the face of challenging environments such as saline soils. We hope that our work will ultimately allow plants to be grown in soils that were previously marginal.  Although most of the work focused on leaf growth, one project looked at regulation of cell division in roots.

In many ways, plant cell division uses similar mechanisms to cell division in animals and fungi, using many of the same proteins.  But one place where plants differ from other organisms is a cell cycle stage called G2, the time between the end of DNA replication and the start of the actual mitotic division process.  The timing of this stage is important, because it provides time for the cell to repair damaged DNA before committing to dividing, as well as allowing time to prepare for the division process itself.  Plants lack a regulatory circuit involving the proteins WEE1 and CDC25 that controls the timing of this stage in other organisms.  One graduate student in the lab demonstrated that a family of cell cycle regulators originally discovered in our lab can regulate the length of G2 in dividing cells in the root, in addition to their role in completely blocking cell division that had been shown earlier.  This work fills an important gap in our understanding of plant cell division.

Another student in the lab has focused her work on leaf development in the plant Schrenkiella parvula, an extremely salt tolerant plant that can grow even when watered with sea water levels of salt. S. parvula is a model for understanding how plants some plants maintain growth in extremely saline conditions, while most crops can tolerate very little salt.  By understanding this, we hope to be able to adapt crops to use soils that are now to salty for agriculture.  Our work to date has found several things. First, the plant deposits higher concentrations of salt in mature leaves than in young developing leaves, suggesting that the plant protects young leaves from salt-induced damage to allow them to complete their growth.  Second, we have found that patterns of gene expression in leaves in young developing leaves vs. mature S. parvula leaves change very differently in response to salt. For charged ions to cross membranes, specific ion channels are necessary.  A challenge for the plant is to let essential ions, like potassium, into the cell while keeping toxic sodium ions out as much as possible. We found that in young S. parvula leaves, treatment with salt changes which ion channel genes were expressed in ways that would tend to limit entry of sodium ions.  In contrast, gene expression changes in mature leaves indicated that these older leaves were not able to keep out as much sodium, but were adapting to deal with the stress.  This fits our hypothesis that the plant uses mature leaves as a “sink” for sodium ions, prioritizing young developing leaves for protection so that growth is not stunted. 

Another related project is based on the observation that S. parvula has narrower and slightly thicker leaves that closely related salt-sensitive plants. Leaves need to capture light and allow carbon dioxide into the leaf for photosynthesis, but leaves also lose water in the process of letting in carbon dioxide.  For this reason, plants from dry and/or saline environments often have reduced leaf area to reduce water loss.  We are attempting to understand how the narrow leaf shape of S. parvula arises by comparing gene expression at seven stages of leaf development in S. parvula and two related salt-sensitive species that have broader leaves.  We have a great deal of data and some preliminary analysis on this project, but we have a ways to go to complete our analysis and draw conclusions.

Broader Impacts:

This project contributed to the training of two graduate students who worked primarily on this project in the Larkin, both of whom have completed their degrees, and contributed to the training of one postdoc in the Dassanayake lab. It also contributed to the training of two undergraduate researchers, one of whom is now a graduate student at Washington State University.
